awd_titl_txt: Conference: Chemistry Early Career Investigator Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
Faculty beginning their independent careers often find the process of writing their first grant proposals to be challenging. Community faculty leaders Corinna Schindler of the University of Michigan and Osvaldo Gutierrez of Texas A&M University are organizing a workshop that seeks to provide new chemistry faculty insight into the proposal writing and reviewing process so that they can identify and develop strong research, education, and outreach activities. Participants will have the opportunity to network with each other as well as successful grant recipients and federal program officers from a variety of agencies. The participants will engage in mock panels, research presentations, and other activities designed to provide them with a better understanding of how to put together a research plan that is ambitious, yet realistic and compelling. Broader impact criteria are also discussed in terms of educational activities, outreach, and technical applications to societal problems. 

The 2023 Chemistry Early Career Investigator Workshop, supported by the Division of Chemistry is planned for Spring 2023 in Alexandria, Virginia. This workshop will bring together up to 100 junior faculty from a broad range of institutions and demographics to discuss steps in strategically crafting research ideas, planning educational and outreach activities, and assessing and evaluating project aims.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

por.por_cntn:
As in the past, the major goal of the NSF CHE Early CAREER Investigator workshop proposal is to provide early career chemists withnetworking opportunities and relevant information needed to better assess their research ideas, projects, and plans so as toeffectively compete for grant applications to the NSF CAREER program, other NSF programs, and other federal agencies. Specifically, during this workshop, in collaboration with various faculty with prior experience writing sucessful NSF grant proposals and program officers from various funding organizations,  we developed a series of professional events to plan for these investigators: (1)to understand the proposal review process at NSF, with a particular emphasis on CAREER proposals (2) to think critically about integrating research, educational, and outreach plans effectively to support a fruitful academiccareer (3) to select the proper funding channels for a variety of proposals (4) to align their research activities with funding opportunities (5) to determine the proper scope of a fundable project (6) to evaluate critically research ideas, projects, and plans (7) to provide a platform for early career chemists to network with peers. Overall,  the participants were excited to contribute to the workshop. Feedback obtained fromthe participants was unanimously positive. 

A) Participants praised activities that allow them to evaluate proposals in groups,engaging with new ideas and people (i.e., active learning); these were by far themost highly reviewed portions of previous workshops.

B) Attendees especially appreciated insights and advice that cannot be obtainedonline (e.g., advice from CAREER awardees and insights from program officersduring mock panel reviews).

C) Attendees liked meeting and working with program officers and would appreciatemore structured opportunities for interacting. Some attendees felt it was too difficult

 

 

 

to get one-on-one time with a program officer or did not realize that was a possibility.

D) It was beneficial to have a diverse set of CAREER awardees serving as invitedparticipants, representing a variety of schools, to give attendees informal advicefrom a different perspective than program officers.

Key outcomes or Otherachievements:

 


Last Modified: 11/21/2024
Modified by: Osvaldo Gutierrez
